distro.desc:
# Debian

Debian is a versatile and stable Linux distribution that forms the foundation for various other popular distributions. Known for its commitment to free and open-source software principles, Debian provides a robust and reliable operating system suitable for servers, desktops, and embedded systems. With a focus on stability, security, and adherence to the Debian Free Software Guidelines, it has become a cornerstone in the Linux ecosystem.

Debian's roots trace back to 1993 when Ian Murdock envisioned a distribution that would be open, community-driven, and dedicated to the principles of the Free Software Movement. Since then, Debian has evolved into a robust and diverse project with a strong emphasis on inclusivity, diversity, and collaboration.

Features and Philosophy

Debian follows the philosophy of providing a truly free and open-source operating system. It prioritizes users' freedom and aims to ensure that users can modify, distribute, and share the software. The Debian Social Contract and the Debian Free Software Guidelines outline the project's commitment to these principles.

One of Debian's distinguishing features is its package management system. The Advanced Package Tool (APT) simplifies the process of installing, upgrading, configuring, and removing software packages. It ensures smooth dependency resolution, making it easy for users to manage software on their systems.

Debian supports a wide range of hardware architectures, making it suitable for various devices, from personal computers to servers and embedded systems. The stability of Debian makes it a preferred choice for servers and critical environments where reliability is paramount.

Basic Commands

Debian users interact with the system using a set of commands that form the foundation of package management and system administration. Here are some essential commands:

  • apt-get update: Update package information. This command retrieves the latest package lists from the repositories and ensures your system has the latest information about available packages.
  • apt-get install [package]: Install a new package. Use this command to download and install a specified package and its dependencies.
  • dpkg -i [package.deb]: Install a local Debian package. This command installs a package from a local .deb file.
  • apt-get upgrade: Upgrade installed packages. This command upgrades all installed packages to their latest versions.
  • apt-get dist-upgrade: Upgrade the entire distribution. This command performs a distribution-wide upgrade, handling dependencies intelligently.
  • apt-get remove [package]: Remove a package. Use this command to uninstall a specified package while keeping its configuration files.
  • dpkg -L [package]: List files installed by a package. This command shows a list of files installed by a specified package.

Sub-Distributions

Debian's influence extends beyond its official releases, serving as the base for various popular distributions. Let's explore some of the notable Debian-based distributions.

Kali Linux

Pros:

  • Comprehensive set of pre-installed security tools.
  • Focused on penetration testing and forensics.

Cons:

  • May not be suitable for general-purpose use.
  • Steep learning curve for beginners.

Linux Mint

Pros:

  • User-friendly and intuitive interface.
  • Stable and reliable.
  • Large and supportive community.

Cons:

  • Not as bleeding-edge as some distributions.
  • Limited pre-installed applications compared to other distros.

elementary OS

Pros:

  • Stunning and cohesive design.
  • Intuitive and user-friendly.
  • Curated set of applications for consistency.

Cons:

  • Limited software availability in the AppCenter.
  • May not appeal to users who prefer more customization.

Ubuntu

Pros:

  • User-friendly.
  • Vast software repository.
  • LTS releases for stability.

Cons:

  • Some proprietary software included.
  • Desktop environment preferences.

kaliLinux.title: Kali Linux
kaliLinux.oneLiner: Kali Linux is a Debian-derived Linux distribution designed for digital forensics, penetration testing, and security auditing, equipped with a wide range of tools for ethical hacking and cybersecurity tasks.

linuxMint.title: Linux Mint
linuxMint.oneLiner: Linux Mint is a user-friendly, Ubuntu-based Linux distribution that prioritizes ease of use and a familiar desktop environment, offering a stable and efficient operating system for desktop users.

elementaryOS.title: elementary OS
elementaryOS.oneLiner: elementary OS is a user-friendly Linux distribution that focuses on simplicity, aesthetics, and a cohesive user experience, featuring the Pantheon desktop environment and a curated set of applications for a polished and intuitive interface.

ubuntu.title: Ubuntu
ubuntu.oneLiner: Ubuntu is a widely-used, user-friendly Linux distribution based on Debian, known for its ease of use, regular release cycles, strong community support, and widespread compatibility.
